awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Reframing Notions of Wet vs. Dry Subduction:  The Search for a Deep Fluid Signature in Subducted Continental Crust Using Coupled O, B, and Fe Isotopes
awd_abstract_narration:
Subduction zones represent not only the main mechanism of mass transfer between the Earth's surface and interior, but also the setting for a majority of large earthquakes and a source of significant volcanic activity, both of which have dramatic and direct effects on human civilization. The presence, scale, and nature of fluids in deep portions of subduction zones are undoubtedly important factors in the generation of both earthquakes and magma, and therefore must be identified and characterized. This study will contribute to our current understanding of deep fluids in subduction zones, and potentially establish a new method for studying them. It would also, as the title suggests, reframe notions of wet versus dry subduction, which may open the door to other ideas and methods for studying subduction zone processes. This project will provide training and research opportunities for a diverse group of graduate and undergraduate students. Outreach activities at local GK-12 schools will expose potential future scientists to cutting edge Earth Science.

Small volumes of continental crust surrounded by oceanic crust may be subducted to ultrahigh-pressure (UHP) depths and exhumed in the early stages of orogeny. These small, subducted blocks of continental crust can preserve evidence of large-scale, deep subduction fluid metasomatism. This team hypothesizes that the Tso Morari terrane, a young UHP locality in the NW Himalaya, represents a small, early-subducted continental mass that likely experienced metasomatism at UHP in the subduction zone. Recent advances have led to novel isotopic and geochemical proxies to fingerprint the origin of subduction-derived fluids and melts both in exhumed subduction materials and arc magmas. In particular, boron is expected to be enriched in devolatilized fluids and depleted in the corresponding host rocks with boron isotopic values providing a sensitive indication of the extent of devolatilization. Additionally, iron isotope systematics are emerging as a potentially powerful tracer of the nature of slab derived fluids. This project will combine these novel proxies with the more established and traditional tracers of subduction fluids, including oxygen isotopes, thermodynamic and fluid modeling, bulk-rock geochemistry, ferrous/ferric iron ratios on a suite of UHP rocks and associated ophiolite/melange from the Tso Morari.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The theory of plate tectonics explains large-scale geological phenomena, such as volcanoes, earthquakes, and the existence of ocean basins and continents. Among the fundamental components of the plate tectonics model are convergent plate margins, aka subduction zones, which are the primary sites of chemical exchange between the Earth’s surface and interior. The release of fluids and silicate melts from the subducting plate, followed by migration and infiltration of these fluids into surrounding rocks, results in mass transfer, element cycling, fluid-mineral reactions, crustal melting, and is thought to trigger deep earthquakes . Therefore, it is of paramount importance to study the origin of these deep fluids and attempt to understand how they interact with rocks at a wide range of depths in the subduction channel and overlying mantle wedge.  

The over-arching goal of this project was to identify and characterize the history fluid-rock reactions in a subduction zone setting using the rocks of the Tso Morari ultrahigh pressure (UHP) terrane in NW India. The intent was to employ a whole-system approach, including measurements of boron, iron, and oxygen isotopes, geochemical and thermodynamic modeling, combined with whole-rock geochemistry and detailed mineralogy, to gain an in-depth understanding of the chemical exchange and isotope cycling occurring at various depths along the subduction zone.

Over the course of this grant, the Principal Investigators, students and postdocs have worked to achieve the main research aims of the proposal. Rock samples from the Tso Morari were prepared for imaging and analyses while preserving parts of each sample for chemical and isotopic analyses.  Compositional data was obtained X-ray fluorescence and mass spectrometry for each sample.  Select samples were also analyzed for Fe, O, and B isotopes, as well as the oxidation state of iron-rich minerals. Extensive thermodynamic modeling was employed to track the fluid history of the Tso Morari terrane throughout the subduction process.  

Our major results so far are listed below:

1)    Thermodynamic modelling combined with detailed microscopy and geochemistry of samples from the Tso Morari UHP terrane identified three major stages of fluid-rock interactions to have occurred during subduction and subsequent exhumation.

2)    During the first fluid stage, minerals in the subducting plate were dehydrated as pressure and temperature increased with increasing depth. Specifically, these reactions occurred as the metamorphic mineral, garnet, began to form and continued until the rocks reached peak pressure (29.0 ± 0.8 kbar and 591 ± 9 °C).

3)    The second fluid stage occurred as the rocks made their way back up to the surface of the Earth from depth, resulting in the formation of a minor amount of new, hydrous minerals.

4)    The third fluid stage occurred slightly later along the exhumation path and resulted in the formation of a rock type called amphibolite, which contains abundant hydrous minerals.

This project supported the training and professional development of multiple undergraduate students and a PhD student who successfully transitioned to a postdoctoral position upon completion of his degree.  Undergraduate and graduate students were trained in essential research skills as well as science communication.  All were able to present research findings at national conferences. A website was created to teach undergraduate students how to conduct thermodynamic modeling and apply it to research in metamorphic terranes. This website is used in Mineralogy and Petrology courses and contains examples from this project that students learn from directly.

Our research results were shared within the scientific community through peer-reviewed journal articles and presentations at conferences. Teaching tools for undergraduate classes were also created as part of the project and are available to anyone in the field through a public website.
